newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Midwest direct hogs steady-up $1.50 - dealers.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Midwest direct hogs steady-up $1.50 - dealers.

text.p: U.S. Midwest direct hog prices early Friday were mostly unchanged to $1.50 per cwt higher, with gains powered by strong packer demand and light hog numbers, livestock dealers said.
Mnrketings in Iowa and Minnesota were adequate for packer demand, but tight in Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, they said.

Interior Iowa and southern Minnesota hogs sold $0.50 higher in the country at $54.50 to $55.00 and steady at plants, with a top of $57.00. Competition for hogs in Illinois was so intense that at least one major packer paid $2.50 premiums over USDA's quoted top Thursday of $55.50, sources there said.
Illinois hogs sold $0.50 to $1.50 higher at $55.50 to $57.00 in the country and up to $58.00 for plant delivery.
Indiana hogs sold $1.50 higher at $55.00 t0 $55.50 in the country and $56.50 to $57.00 at plants.
"The sun is still shining and people are out farming, which means not many hogs," an Indiana hog dealer said.
Ohio hogs sold $1.00 higher, with a top of $54.00 in the country and $56.00 at plants.
Strong packer demand was fortified by steep gains in pork prices on Thursday. Pork cut-out values Thursday were quoted up $0.95 to $1.01 per cwt, USDA reported.
